channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: A woman in the New York City area appears to have been cured of HIV after a stem-cell transplant from umbilical-cord blood, providing researchers with a road map to beat one of nature’s most resilient viruses https://t.co/Ik2lQXbQbM
P.J. O'Rourke, an irreverent political satirist, author and panelist on NPR’s quiz show, “Wait, Wait…Don’t Tell Me!”, has died at age 74 from lung cancer complications https://t.co/OCtwWyIi7T
Mark Zuckerberg has a new nickname for his employees: "metamates" https://t.co/7UVpZF6pGN
Special counsel John Durham says Hillary Clinton allies sought to improperly use internet data to link Donald Trump to Russia. Defense lawyers call it groundless. https://t.co/6JC2Aiban7
The SEC is examining links between the U.S. arm of Binance, the world's largest crypto exchange, and trading firms tied to its founder, people familiar say https://t.co/ryVa5Gvesl

This week and next, if conditions are right, a waterfall in Yosemite National Park in California will glow a fiery, bright orange at sunset for a few minutes in a rare annual phenomenon called "firefall" https://t.co/JIYoBu8Cry
Ukraine is threatened by a new conflict with Russia. The old conflict has already cost the lives of at least 14,000 Ukrainians and billions of dollars. https://t.co/EgPf6tjyex

San Francisco voters decide today whether to recall three members of the city’s school board, which has been accused of focusing more on social-justice issues than reopening campuses during the pandemic https://t.co/BtTq5CtHW7
From @WSJopinion: Special Counsel John Durham continues to unravel the Trump-Russia “collusion” story, and his latest court disclosure contains startling information https://t.co/OqgXqUnQwj
Jailed Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny faces up to 15 years in prison as a new trial opens, in the Putin government’s latest salvo against Russia’s opposition https://t.co/y2rXxBQsjF

The Trump Organization’s accounting firm has disavowed years of financial statements it prepared for Donald Trump and his company, saying the documents “should not be relied upon,” according to court filings https://t.co/8zf2dOoJaa

Babies born to mothers who got vaccinated during pregnancy were significantly less likely to be hospitalized for Covid-19, a study led by federal researchers showed, adding to growing evidence of the benefits of maternal vaccination https://t.co/TLhHdqEumu

U.S. prosecutors allege that former Honduran President Juan Orlando Hernández received millions of dollars in bribes from drug smugglers who shipped tons of cocaine to the U.S. https://t.co/l86s84O0Yd
Texas sued Meta over Facebook’s use of facial-recognition technology, saying it violated the state’s privacy protections for personal biometric data https://t.co/PBb5RWvi7y

Russia said it had pulled back some troops from the Ukraine border, but large-scale exercises continue. Mixed military signals from Moscow came as Germany’s chancellor arrived for talks with Putin. https://t.co/fx92EUGytq

Men’s tennis world No. 1 Novak Djokovic will continue to refuse vaccination for Covid-19, even if it costs him the chance to win more tournaments, he said in an interview broadcast by the BBC on Tuesday https://t.co/Xd3cOzO8WI
Elon Musk donated roughly $5.7 billion worth of Tesla shares to charity last year, according to a securities filing, as he conducted a series of stock sales https://t.co/9nGR4wx8Yn
Russia said it had pulled back some troops from near Ukraine, but large-scale military exercises are continuing and other combat units are moving forward https://t.co/FQFHiB2Bfq

Levi’s President Jennifer Sey said she has left the apparel giant, citing clashes with colleagues, including the company’s CEO, over her public views regarding Covid-19 restrictions in schools https://t.co/NiJXAVWZsw
Elon Musk donated roughly $5.7 billion worth of Tesla shares to charity last year, according to a securities filing, as he conducted a series of stock sales https://t.co/U79YRUGqtH
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/2Wg52eTGSY https://t.co/jGS09wZSwF

Federal investigators are probing block trading on Wall Street, examining whether bankers may have improperly tipped hedge-fund clients in advance of large share sales, people familiar with the situation said https://t.co/73Acj2JiAK

From @WSJopinion: Biden has three years left in his term, and the world’s rogues won’t wait until 2024 for the U.S. to get its act together. He needs to unite the country in response to the growing global threats. https://t.co/4E2jV105Gx
Texas sued Meta over Facebook’s use of facial-recognition technology, saying it violated the state’s privacy protections for personal biometric data https://t.co/Ep6absvhPb

A federal judge said he will reject Sarah Palin’s allegations that she was defamed by the New York Times, ruling that the former Republican vice-presidential candidate’s claims presented at trial were insufficient to prove her case https://t.co/xV7ghSpMxw
The White House Correspondents’ Association’s gala is returning for the first time since the Covid-19 pandemic began. Trevor Noah will host the event, set for April 30. https://t.co/puGMa4YurL

The U.S. is closing its embassy in the Ukrainian capital of Kyiv and relocating operations 340 miles west to Lviv near the Polish border, as allies warn that an attack by Russian forces on Ukraine may be imminent https://t.co/dUVDY0JBJ7
Germany’s chancellor is traveling to Ukraine and Russia in the West’s latest diplomatic effort to avert a potential attack by Moscow on its neighbor https://t.co/DRAzM3CqA9
From @WSJopinion: Canada is no longer a liberal constitutional state. A coercive Ottawa rules over daily life, writes @MaryAnastasiaOG. https://t.co/BMIf7JXnJV
Ukraine has become the focus of global attention as Russia builds up troops on its border and NATO allies respond. Here's a look at the origins of the standoff. https://t.co/Rk56bnonyd
From @WSJopinion: Every generation of Americans has fulfilled its duty to support and defend the Constitution. That responsibility now falls to us, writes @RepLizCheney. https://t.co/vd1vDYZ4cz

An international court cleared Kamila Valieva to compete in the women’s individual figure skating event, but Olympic officials said that no medal ceremony will be held after if she finishes among the top three https://t.co/vrjzlviqFZ
Tom Brady may go down as the National Football League’s most accomplished quarterback, but in Brazil he is simply “Giselo,” the husband of supermodel Gisele Bündchen https://t.co/9RkGC27hQq
The threat of a Russian invasion of Ukraine is shaking up a fragile global oil market, pushing prices closer to $100 a barrel https://t.co/WkXTYyLDuf
Google, Amazon, Meta and Microsoft are building an empire under the ocean https://t.co/0bkuVwflzg
Most young adults believe it’s best to delay marriage past your 20s and to live together first. New research challenges both assumptions. https://t.co/Xvmp7hAXHk

Eminem took a knee during the Super Bowl halftime performance, a gesture that echoed the protests launched by Colin Kaepernick against racial injustice that roiled the National Football League for years. https://t.co/seldQ9pYVA
The Los Angeles Rams won the Super Bowl, defeating the Cincinnati Bengals, 23-20. It's the team's second title and the first since it moved from St. Louis. https://t.co/v8FNDROvRh
Russia’s military buildup near Ukraine features some of its most potent weapon systems and best-trained troops, allowing for a multi-pronged attack https://t.co/Rtcpyg7llH
President Biden told Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky Sunday that the U.S. and its allies would respond rapidly to any further Russian aggression against his country https://t.co/DWTYg1k7QH
National security adviser Jake Sullivan says the U.S. is prepared for “the potential of a major military action in the coming days” in the Russia-Ukraine conflict https://t.co/aLb9TgiCF9
Ukrainian officials say Russia has a new destabilization tactic: hundreds of false bomb threats https://t.co/IEVcqSwmid
Ukrainian skeleton racer Vladyslav Heraskevych was aware of Olympic rules barring political statements during competitions. He thought the risk was worth it. https://t.co/JOjPPobPsA

Erin Jackson, a 29-year-old from Florida who has spent most of her life skating on land, not ice—and years in the roller derby rink—became an Olympic champion in the 500 meters https://t.co/DW4GnF0XBp
Hong Kong residents are chafing at life under new restrictions, the toughest since the Covid-19 pandemic began, even as much of the world is starting to move on https://t.co/JnpwTNM0n5
Canadian police began arresting protesters in a renewed effort to clear access to a crucial bridge connecting the U.S. with Canada https://t.co/wVHeNl9Tdx
Ukrainian officials say Russia has a new destabilization tactic: hundreds of false bomb threats https://t.co/QSjHCXA5Dp
You’ve been exposed to Covid-19 more times than you can count, but never tested positive. Here’s what scientists say about the effect on your immune system. https://t.co/CdYKwcfA4k

From @WSJopinion: The stage-managed Olympics can’t conceal economic worries. If Xi Jinping isn’t enjoying the festivities, that may be due to fresh signs the economy is in trouble—which is largely his fault. https://t.co/GhIM7eqeoa
Ukrainian skeleton racer Vladyslav Heraskevych was aware of Olympic rules barring political statements during competitions. He thought the risk was worth it. https://t.co/2h2fxEbwA4
